p: Mankind has learned to live with infectious disease outbreaks. History is full of diseases, such as the plague, smallpox or cholera ravaging continents in times where there were no therapies or economic ways to battle them [ 1]. The medical, economic and social achievements of the past 150 years have made a change. Still, every outbreak is a challenge as if it was the first one. One reason is the nature of man, putting preparations off when menacing scenarios are not an immediate threat. Bill Gates stated some years ago at the Munich Security Conference that he “views the threat of deadly pandemics right up there with nuclear war and climate change”, and “that we need to prepare for epidemics the way the military prepares for war” ( https://www.gatesfoundation.org/Media-Center/Speeches/2017/05/Bill-Gates-Munich-Security-Conference). It is obvious that the world has not been guided by the same conviction [ 2].
